definition: abbr. for 書經|书经[Shu1 jing1]

sentences.english: In other words, banned books are sometimes readily available.
sentences.chinese: 换句话说，禁书有时也是垂手可得的。

sentences.english: So, in lieu of books, the new trend seems to be banning fat.
sentences.chinese: 于是，继禁书之后，新的趋势似乎是要禁脂肪。

sentences.english: We are fond of reading but there are still illiterates they must be consent to banning the book.
sentences.chinese: 我们爱读书，还有不识字的人呢，他们准赞成禁书。

sentences.english: The commissar insisted on indexing the book.
sentences.chinese: 政委坚持将此书列为禁书。

sentences.english: Jiang Jieshi has also implemented the policy he banned, banned the book not less than.
sentences.chinese: 蒋介石也实行禁书政策，他查禁的书不会少于清朝。

sentences.english: If there is no" price policy", is not the" pleasure".
sentences.chinese: 如果没有“禁书政策”，是不会产生这种“乐事”的。

sentences.english: Chin Shengt'an regards reading a banned book behind closed doors on a snowy night as one of the greatest pleasures of life.
sentences.chinese: 金圣叹认为雪夜闭户读禁书，是人生最大的乐趣。

sentences.english: We love books, but there still are many who can’t read and certainly they agree on banning books.
sentences.chinese: 我们爱读书，还有不识字的人呢，他们准赞成禁书。

sentences.english: So" on door read banned" became a feudal era.
sentences.chinese: 所以“雪夜闭门读禁书”成为封建时代一大乐事。

definition: to promote sex and violence/to stir up lust and covetousness
Jinpingmei or the Golden Lotus (1617), Ming dynasty vernacular novel, formerly notorious and banned for its sexual content
manuscript copy of a book (before the printing press)
the Twenty-Four Histories (25 or 26 in modern editions), collection of books on Chinese dynastic history from 3000 BC till 17th century/fig. a long and complicated story
Decameron, collection of 100 tales of love supposedly told by ten young people in ten days, written by Giovanni Boccaccio 薄伽丘[Bo2 jia1 qiu1]
twenty four dynastic histories (or 25 or 26 in modern editions)
forged book/book of dubious authenticity/misattributed book/Apocrypha
